newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila forex deals trade hits record $254 mln.
newsitem.headline: Manila forex deals trade hits record $254 mln.

text.p: Turnover on the Manila foreign exchange market hit a record $254 million in intraday trading on Friday as the Philippine peso rebounded from false rumours that the national defence chief had been killed, the Bankers Association of the Philippines said.
Traders said the market is now being swamped with dollars for stock market investments and from unloading banks which had bought dollars on late Thursday as the rumour injected panic.

The Bankers Association of the Philippines said the current volume in the foreign exchange market exceeded the $236.50 million posted in July 13, 1995 and the $232 million in Feb 14, 1996 when the market also went into a frenzy in the wake of grenade attacks in the financial district of Makati.
The Central Bank is now offering to buy dollars at 26.201 pesos from an earlier 26.202 pesos, traders said. They estimate the Central Bank has now gobbled up about $100 million from the market.
The peso is now trading at 26.205 pesos, up from its previous close of 26.225 pesos. Volume has further risen to $262 million.
The peso was hammered to a low of 26.235 pesos on Thursday as the rumour spread across the market.
